Award.AwardTitle: Chemical Methods to Control Charge Transfer at Nanoscale Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this project is to develop methods to control electron/energy transfer processes at interfaces involving chemically synthesized nanoscale inorganic materials. This control will be achieved through the solution-based assembly of multiple inorganic components (metallic, semiconducting, and/or insulating) with, in some cases, functional organic molecules. For initial study, three systems of fundamental scientific and commercial importance are targeted: (1) ionic surface coatings for controlling doping and interfacial electric fields in nanoparticle assemblies; (2) organic-functionalized semiconducting nanoparticles to drive spatially controlled photochemical polymerizations; and (3) nanoparticles with multicomponent nanoscale inorganic coatings for solar-to-chemical energy conversion. These research efforts will be student-driven, with continued focus on scientific career training for female and minority students, and will take place in the scientifically rich, cutting-edge, multi-disciplinary environment at UC Santa Barbara. The graduate students working on the project will serve as mentors to undergraduate students, high school teachers, and high school students through NSF- and DoD-funded outreach programs and informal collaborations.

Nanoscale materials with useful electronic and light-absorbing properties, made using inexpensive and scalable chemical methods, could positively impact important industries ranging from energy conversion, electronics, and catalysis to use in chemical sensing, biotechnology and health care. In order to achieve the societal benefits associated with such a transformation, we are working to synthetically control, using molecules and inorganic coatings, the way in which electrons move and interact in this emerging class of materials. These research efforts will be student-driven, with continued focus on scientific career training for female and minority students, and will take place in the scientifically rich, cutting-edge, multi-disciplinary environment at UC Santa Barbara. The graduate students working on the project will serve as mentors to undergraduate students, high school teachers, and high school students through NSF- and DoD-funded outreach programs and informal collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoscale materials with useful electronic and light-absorbing properties, made using inexpensive and scalable chemical methods, could positively impact important industries ranging from energy conversion, electronics, and catalysis to use in chemical sensing, biotechnology and health care. This project studied the way in which electrons move and interact in certain inorganic materials.  The overall goal was to develop new methods to control electron transfer processes at interfaces involving either isolated or assembled nanoscale inorganic components.

 

Our approach was define and control what are typically limiting aspects of system functionality, namely the charge (electron, ion)/energy transfer processes, energetics, and spatial heterogeneity associated with the tailor-designed nanostructured components and interfaces of the system. The components of interest included inorganic, organic, polymeric, and biomolecular species. We sought to synthesize and understand novel 3-D hierarchically structured composite systems that exhibit responsive chemical, optical, or electronic functionality. Following nature's paradigm, our synthetic approach was to engineer the components and total system using emergent, multiscale molecular solution-based methods and/or surface modification techniques to create functional integrated components that can be addressed and provide synergistic multifunctionality.

 

These research efforts took place in the scientifically rich, cutting-edge, multi-disciplinary environment at UC Santa Barbara.  The participants were visiting researchers from Europe and Asia and about a dozen UCSB graduate and postdoctoral students, who are now pursuing careers in academia and the chemical industry.  Over the years they served as mentors to undergraduate students, high school teachers, and high school students through NSF- and DoD-funded outreach programs and informal collaborations.  Collaborations with and among the participants are continuing.

 

Many specific projects were undertaken over the course of the grant.  A common theme of many of the specific projects was to enable the creation of sustainable and efficient energy conversion and storage systems using earth-abundant materials.  We explored, for example, synthesis of high-surface-area semiconductors and metals with nanostructured inorganic coatings for total solar spectrum-to-chemical energy conversion as well as system validation of high-capacity, chemically stable, porous, metallic binary/ternary transition metal nitrides for electrochemical energy storage and as anode materials for advanced battery types. 

 

We succeeded in creating a plasmonic water-splitting cell in which 95% of the effective charge carriers derive from surface plasmon decay to hot electrons. This showed that by engineering a device that incorporates an array of aligned gold nanorods, functioning as a plasmonic nanostructure with a high surface area, in contact with titania, one can improve the visible solar to-fuel conversion efficiency so that it greatly exceeds its UV efficiency and shows unprecedented oxygen evolution ability when illuminated with visible light.
